title: In Husted v. A. Philip Randolph Institute, will the Supreme Court rule that Ohio's supplemental process for voter registration list-maintenance is legal?
preds: Just testing what my score will be for jumping in after the fact.

Fantasy Scotus rates this 6-3.  Maintainence of election lists is a state responsibility something mentioned a few times in recent cases.   Plaintiffs would have you believe that the trigger is the failure to vote, something expressly prohibited by the motor voter bill.  However, it is not.  It is failure to vote AND failure to vote in the next 4 years AND failure to respond to the address of record.    Plus most people can register to vote easily; some on the same day of election.  This is reasonable for the maintenance of lists.
The court seemed to focus on the fact that the purge was a multi step process, not purely due to inactivity, which should sway the decision

It's a bit dated, but  " Supreme Court Reversal Rates:  Evaluating the Federal Courts of Appeals"  (Roy E. Hofer) indicate at the 6th circuit had 45 reversals + 6 vacate, and 19 affirmed rulings from the Supreme Court from 1999-2008.  Pr=0.73.    Time constraint with note taken of current electoral affect and related anxiety.  Specification that ruling find Ohio's supplemental process is legal.
The process will be seen to be relatively non-partisan and easily remedied by purged voters.

Originally had a much lower prediction, but re-read the transcript and focused on Justice Breyer's concerns with respondents. It does sound like the process will be deemed legal, though maybe the exact "content of confirmation notices" will need to be tweaked.

The argument that the simple failure to vote is included - as one of many possible reasons for removal from voter registration - means that ALL possible reasons are equally valid and effectively indistinguishable; thus the supplemental process is invalid under the provisions of National Voter Registration Act of 1993 and the Help America Vote Act of 2002.
Breyer and the five conservatives expressed concerns about how to otherwise regulate the voting list. 6-3 for Husted.

Federal law explicitly provides an acceptable method for culling aging voter registration rolls and Ohio is using just that method. The 6th Circuit is over-reaching by effectively ignoring that  intended process under the guise of the limits it imposes preventing any other methods of purging voter rolls. The section they state as having supremacy was a catch-all with the exception being the one method/allowance outlined. It is extremely strange to interpret a law that provides an explicit method/allowance for maintaining updated voter rolls such that later aspects of the law completely nullifying that explicitly stated allowance.
Although the intention of Ohio's process is to disenfranchise voters they found a legal way to do it. :(
likely but need more qualifying factors

The court will look carefully at the previous decisions in this case and the applicable law, and it will rule narrowly.  Voting roll maintenance is a necessary government function, and there will be an inclination to allow a state to do it in any reasonable way.  I do not have the information needed to decide if this is reasonable.
The court will rule unconstitutional citing violations of due process as the effect of Ohio's current methods results in intentional discrimination of non-white and transient populations.

http://www.scotusblog.com/2018/01/argument-analysis-ohio-voter-registration-practices-safe/
"In what could be an ominous sign for the challengers, Breyer seemed frustrated that states were left with what he seemed to regard as an impossible task. How, he asked Smith, are states supposed to track people who die or move out of state, to figure out whether they need to be removed from voter-registration lists? “We don’t want them on the voter roll,” Breyer declared. “That used to be a big problem, voting dead people.” He picked up this line of questioning again later on, telling Smith that he didn’t “believe Congress would have passed a statute that would prevent a state from purging a voting roll of people who have died or have moved out of the state.”
Kennedy repeated this sentiment, telling Smith that states were purging registration lists “to protect the voter rolls from people” who have moved and are “voting in the wrong district.”" Who knows after the argument analysis by Ms. Howe above

Surely there should be other ways to fight voter fraud, but why do you guys put the probability so low? @magoo made a good point saying that SCOTUS tends to reverse this Circuit (http://ellisp.github.io/blog/2017/02/26/appeal-circuits). Besides, I read on SCOTUSblog that this case was taken even though there is no "Circuit split" on the issue. Makes me guess even higher.

meaning supplied by the structure of the entire
statute, which indicates that states are free to send
confirmation notices on any nondiscriminatory and
uniform basis"
Unless the state can show that these voters need to be removed for a purpose, i don't think it will be ruled as legal

Purging voters from the rolls who don't vote within a 2 or 4 year period and the practical effect that had in Ohio (40,000 voters purged) undermines one of America's fundamental tenants:  the right to vote.
Outdated lists invite fraud and Ohio's updating procedures are not unreasonable.
I'm goin' with Gibson and lsgold7

Both the 1993 and 2002 federal laws prevent states from removing registered voters if they choose NOT to exercise their right to vote. The Ohio supplemental process uses non-voting as the trigger to begin the process of removing registered citizens from its roles. The federal appellate court reasoned that despite it's condition, the ultimate effect of the law was that voters' removal was triggered solely because they failed to vote. I expect the appellate ruling to stand. https://www.theatlantic.com/politics/archive/2017/05/supreme-court-ohio-voting/528573/
Husted v. Randolph is scheduled for oral argument Jan 10, 2018. This is only an opening bid.

I'm not sure why this made it to SCOTUS. Politics has become so leveraged that even a matter like this - particularly in Ohio, could swing a national election The less attended issue is state sovereignty and the infringement of the courts on their right to run or rig the elections as they see fit through elected representatives.

"Therefore, I would affirm the decision of the district court, except insofar as it declined to
require the Secretary to amend its notice to voters who have moved to other States. I would
grant relief on that sole issue." 
Judge Siler concurred and dissented At Case: 16-3746 Document: 39-2 Filed: 09/23/2016 Page: 22
7 votes for his view I suspect
@JMR2017 @Gibson
I think See The Opinion below
"R, Circuit Judge, dissenting in part and concurring in part. Because of the urgency
of this issue and the need to allow the Supreme Court to consider it, I write the
dissent/concurrence in condensed fashion. It does not reflect the extent to which I disagree with
the majority opinion, although I respect it.
 I commend the Secretary for issuing a new confirmation notice form during the pendency
of this litigation. In all aspects of the law, except for directions on how the voter can continue
his registration, it complies with the National Voter Registration Act of 1993 (NVRA) and the
Help America Vote Act of 2002 (HAVA).
Both sides agree that the language of the NVRA is unambiguous. “If the words of the
statute are unambiguous, the judicial inquiry is at an end, and the plain meaning of the text must
be enforced.” United States v. Plavcak, 411 F.3d 655, 661 (6th Cir. 2005) (quoting Hudson v.
Reno, 130 F.3d 1193, 1196 (6th Cir. 1997)).
This seems to be a much simpler process than as outlined in the majority opinion. The
Secretary has established a Supplemental Process for purging voters from the voting rolls in
Ohio. The key language in the statute attacked by the plaintiffs is from 52 U.S.C. § 20507(b)(2),
which directs that States shall not remove “the name of any person from the official list of voters
registered to vote in an election for Federal office by reason of the person’s failure to vote.”
However, that same subsection allows a State to use “the procedures described in subsections
(c) and (d) to remove an individual from the official list of eligible voters” under certain
circumstances. Id. That subsection indicates that if the voter
(A) has not either notified the applicable registrar (in person or in writing) or responded
during the period described in subparagraph (B) to the notice sent by the applicable
registrar; and then
(B) has not voted or appeared to vote in 2 or more consecutive general elections for
Federal office,
 Case: 16-3746 Document: 39-2 Filed: 09/23/2016 Page: 22
No. 16-3746 A. Philip Randolph Inst., et al. v. Husted Page 23
then subsection (d) provides how States may cancel registrations of those who may have changed
addresses. Id. It provides that the registrant should not be removed from the list of voters unless
he or she confirms that he or she has changed residence or has failed to respond to a notice
described in paragraph (2) and has not voted during a certain period of time. 52 U.S.C.
§ 20507(d)(1).
The part of the statute which is in contention is § 20507(b)(2), which indicates that the
State shall not remove the voter “by reason of the person’s failure to vote.” The Secretary
indicates that the person is not removed from the voting rolls until after the registrant is sent a
notice by mail to find out if he or she still lives at the old address. Not until that person fails to
respond, as plaintiff Larry Harmon did, does the State then list the voter as “inactive” in the
registration database. Nevertheless, this “inactive” voter has all the rights to cast a regular ballot
at any election, but if four years transpire without the registrant’s voting, his or her registration
record is canceled. However, if the registrant has any voting activity during those four years, he
or she returns to an active voter status.
 The text of the NVRA directs the States to “conduct a general program that makes a
reasonable effort to remove the names of ineligible voters from the official lists of eligible voters
by reason of” death or relocation. 52 U.S.C. § 20507(a)(4). The district court found the
Secretary has made a reasonable effort to carry out that mandate, and I agree. The State cannot
remove the registrant’s name from the rolls for a failure to vote only, and Ohio does not do so. It
removes registrants only if (1) they have not voted or updated their registration for the last two
years, (2) also failed to respond to the address-confirmation notice, and (3) then failed to engage
in any voter activity in four consecutive years, including two consecutive Federal elections
following that notice.
 The decision of the district court also follows the language in HAVA. The district court
cited the following language from that act:
[C]onsistent with the National Voter Registration Act of 1993 . . . , registrants
who have not responded to a notice and who have not voted in 2 consecutive
general elections for Federal office shall be removed from the official list of
eligible voters, except that no registrant may be removed solely by reason of a
failure to vote.
 Case: 16-3746 Document: 39-2 Filed: 09/23/2016 Page: 23
No. 16-3746 A. Philip Randolph Inst., et al. v. Husted Page 24
52 U.S.C. § 21083(a)(4). As the Secretary has explained, it is his position that no voter is
removed solely by reason of a failure to vote, and thus he has complied with the language from
both statutes. I agree. The statutes leave it to the States to implement, and Ohio has developed a
lawful procedure.
 On the question of mootness, I agree with the majority that the plaintiffs had standing to
bring the challenge to the notice form when the case was filed. However, I disagree with the
conclusion that this case is not moot because the issues, save one, concerning the confirmation
notice form have been corrected by the Secretary. Cessation of certain “conduct by government
officials has been treated with more solicitude by the courts than similar action by private
parties.” Mosley v. Hairston, 920 F.2d 409, 415 (6th Cir. 1990) (quoting Ragsdale v. Turnock,
841 F.2d 1358, 1365 (7th Cir. 1988)). I agree with the district court that there is no evidence to
show that the Secretary would change the current notice, and this court should give him
deference on that question. However, I concur with the majority that the current notice does not
comply with the NVRA final mandate that when the Secretary sends the confirmation notice that
the registrant has been purged, the notice must provide “information concerning how the
registrant can continue to be eligible to vote.” 52 U.S.C. § 20507(d)(2)(B).
The district court found that this issue was waived by the plaintiffs for failure to include it
in their pleadings before filing their reply brief. However, their motion for summary judgment
argued that the confirmation notice forms do not advise people who have moved out of the State
how they could register in their new State. Although I agree with the district court that the State
officials have been given an “onerous burden of coaching out-of-state residents through the
registration process in their new States of residence,” that is what the statute requires.
The district court ruled that the mandate only applies to give the registrant information about
registering in another location in Ohio, but the language of the statute is broader than that. In
their brief on appeal, plaintiffs have suggested that an easy way to comply would be by directing
voters to the Election Assistance Commission’s website containing the federal form, which
provides instructions and guidance for voter registration in all States. Although such a notice
should be easy to attach to the notification to the registrants, it assumes that all registrants know
 Case: 16-3746 Document: 39-2 Filed: 09/23/2016 Page: 24
No. 16-3746 A. Philip Randolph Inst., et al. v. Husted Page 25
how to utilize websites. Nevertheless, that is the relief which the plaintiffs have requested, and it
seems simple enough for the Secretary to institute that amendment to the notice.
 Therefore, I would affirm the decision of the district court, except insofar as it declined to
require the Secretary to amend its notice to voters who have moved to other states"

Will SC reverse the opinion written by Judge Eric Clay of the 6th Circuit Court of Appeals (appointed by President Bill Clinton)? The case is supposed to be heard in January but no date has been set yet. The advocate for APRI has taken medical leave and another attorney asked to re-schedule in order to get up to speed on the case. Baseline: SC takes cases to reverse decisions around 70% of the time and in the 6th Circuit more like 80% based on decisions from 2005-16. 
Interesting analysis here on the determinants of Supreme Court decisions to reverse lower court decisions. http://www.hangley.com/news/us-supreme-court-decisions-analysis
Metrics include: 1.	Advocacy experience before the Supreme Court matters
2.	Amicus support, particularly from the Solicitor General’s Office, correlates with success before the Court
3.	Ideology matters in at least two ways: First, our analysis shows that a Republican (Democrat) appointed Justice is much less (15.2 percentage points) likely to vote to reverse a conservative (liberal) leaning decision.
Second, they looked at whether a Justice appointed by a President from one political party was less likely to reverse the decision written by a court of appeals judge who was appointed by a President from the same party
4.	Who wrote the Court of Appeals decision under review makes a difference All this is normally interesting to forecasters and can help us make decisions. But as one may have noticed, everything has changed on many fronts since Trump won the Presidency so as usual, harder to predict. I think Kennedy is sensitive to overreach on the part of the administration and Republicans in red states on voting rights issues affected by gerrymandering, voter ID laws, purging of voter roles, etc. The Dept. of Justice has made it clear for the first time in a very long time that their position of defending voting rights has changed. SC knows there is an aggressive approach on the part of the DOJ to encourage purging (letter was sent to 44 states demanding information on their efforts to purge voters).  Solicitor General’s office filed a brief in support of Ohio’s laws.
https://www.justice.gov/sites/default/files/briefs/2017/08/07/16-980_husted_v_randolph_institute_ac_merits.pdf But Kennedy has voted with conservatives on voter ID laws and sided with conservatives on the 2013 Voting Rights Act case to end pre-clearance of changes to voting rights laws in states with records of discrimination.  Shelby County v. Holder Ohio's laws have been in place for many years and compared to other types of voter suppression laws, perhaps not as bad. Although in the 3 largest counties of Ohio, Democratic voters were removed at twice the rate of Republicans as a result of more Republicans voting in mid-term elections.  And race is a proxy for party and vice versa. So given overreach, one can see Kennedy voting to affirm in support of APRI and against Ohio.
On the other hand, Kennedy will never be taken for granted and that’s why he maintains the middle ground. The details of this case seem much less egregious than other iterations of voter suppression... and purging voters from rolls has been around a long time.   I can envision Kennedy deciding with conservatives to reverse the 6th Circuit decision thereby making the supplemental process legal but perhaps adding instructions to improve the process. For example, how about an additional notification to voters well before the election that they will be removed from the rolls if they don't act? One other factor besides Kennedy to consider here is that the case is being heard late and maybe won't get decided in the current term.
I'd like to give it a lower likelihood, because the right to vote should not be taken away so cavalierly. But I'm worried about this court.
It's a procedural process  designed to make the voter rolls current
Failure to exercise your right to vote should not mean that you lose your right to vote. The individual's right to vote will take precedence over the states right to streamline the polling process..

The legal arguments are what they are.  The reality is that at this level, decisions like this are virtually always political, with legal considerations used as filler.  Here's the real issue:  The honourable justices must choose between either  perpetuating the process that led to the recent election result or curtailing that process.  if enough of them are horrified, they will start to reverse the voter-suppression trend; if not, they'll let it stand.   My guess is that at least five and maybe six will wish to restore grown-up government to the extent they can.  Because the actual problems are outside their control (binding open primaries, for example), this intent will be thwarted, but they will have done what they could--in this case, finding for Randolph.  Nobody already on the court can be sacked by M. Petits-Doigts or voted out by anybody, so they may decide instead to see if they can keep the country afloat a bit longer.  Or not.
The court has seemed to want to protect voting rights, I think that trend continues based on how they have ruled in past cases such as refusing to hear an appeal against North Carolina's voting laws.

There is not too much literature on this case so far, besides summaries of arguments so far. I am fairly uncertain of the outcome of this case. My gut feeling tells me it is more likely to rule against the petitioner. Even if the Sixth Circuit's textual reading of the case was flawed, the consequence of the list-maintenance in actively removing voters, in direct relation to whether they voted seems a bit stark. I'm giving my evaluation here slightly more confidence than the Masterpiece case which has more commentary out there for it. In the Masterpiece religious expression case, a lot of the argumentation from established cases with precedents makes it more likely things fall on partisan lines, which can make the voting a lot closer. My general impression is that with cases like this, voting will be less close. I'm trusting my gut a little bit more here, in other words, for lack of other voices. Various Resources:
https://www.oyez.org/cases/2017/16-980
http://www.scotusblog.com/case-files/cases/husted-v-philip-randolph-institute/ Writ of certiorari: http://www.scotusblog.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/02/16-980-cert-petition.pdf
Based on Gore v Bush, I expect SCOTUS to uphold the national legislation in this area.
This could easily go either way

The constitutional right to vote will 'trump' the State's desire to maintain their voting roles; minimize the potential for fraud.  The Court will ask that the State develop a much more proactive & extensive effort to ensure they have taken all reasonable steps to ensure the voting roles accurately reflect those that have the right to vote, regardless of whether they do or don't.  My rationale for a percentage above 0% is due to the current politics of the court

This is a close issue of statutory interpretation of a statute I do not have familiarity with, so my certainty is very low. Still, it appears the 6th Circuit dissent correctly points out that not voting in two consecutive elections is enough to remove a voter from the rolls. Gorsuch is even more of a plain language strict interpretation judge than Scalia.
The court will see this as a legal action to keep the voter rolls accurate.
The existing provide for states to determine voting eligibility.

The National Voter Registration Act and the Help America Vote Act,  both were implemented  to increase the  number of  Registered voters .  Registering to vote affords citizens the opportunity to exercise their voting rights afforded to us  by the Constitution . Their are no specifications  in any statute that requires citizens to be active voters in order to maintain that right. Ohio requiring registered but inactive voters to mail back a form adds an additional requirement to vote. It also violates the spirit and intent of the aforementioned statutes, which is to  make it easier for citizens to vote and increase voter turnout  by removing unnecessary constraints  that would prevent them from registering to vote .

Note: for questions in the SCOTUS challenge I am only using 0 and 100% as answer choices, which is not my assessment of the actual probabilities. My guess: Ohio's supplemental process is illegal = {Roberts, Kennedy, Breyer, Ginsburg, Sotomayor, Kagan}
Ohio's supplemental process is legal = {Thomas, Alito, Gorsuch} Order of confidence in the above classification from greatest to least (assuming all participate):
Thomas
Sotomayor
Alito
Ginsburg
Breyer
Kagan
Kennedy
Gorsuch
Roberts (I don't know how Gorsuch feels about these issues and haven't looked. Edit: looks like Gorsuch did sit on a 3-judge panel that enforced a different part of one of the voting rights statutes at issue, but (a) he didn't write the opinion and (b) the case is about a different part of the statute. Valdez v. Squier, 676 F.3d 935 (10th Cir. 2012).) Note also, Gorsuch is often compared with his predecessor Scalia. It may be worth comparing his vote on the Hudson v. Phillip Randolph Institute decision to Scalia's vote in Arizona v. Inter Tribal Council of Arizona, 133 S. Ct. 2247 (2013) in which Scalia wrote for the majority; I don't know whether Gorsuch would've voted the same way Scalia did in Arizona v. Inter Tribal Council... On the other hand, the relevant facts and parts of law are arguably quite different from one of those cases to the next.
The supreme court will affirm the lower court's ruling

I think this will come down as a 5-4 decision, based upon the make-up of the current court. And with the amount of evidence that supports the assertions of voting fraud specific to Ohio (if that evidence is considered), I expect the court to make the right decision and say that voting integrity is more important than just some extra people voting.
The Court won't want to interfere with state election laws.

On the face of it, the Ohio process is blatantly illegal, and it is unlikely that members of the US Supreme Court are unaware of its intent.  Nonetheless, it would be jake with the late Justice Scalia, who never met a voter-suppression law he didn't like.  There is some suspicion that at least the CJ suffers from occasional integrity, and even Nino's successor might if the case is obvious enough.   My wishy-washy number expresses mild hope for the rule of law; stay tuned. Not clear how this will be resolved if the Court decides that the various complainants (who don't seem to include any actual struck voters, but I need to check on that some more) lack standing.  The Court can thus duck the legality issue entirely.  I guess this means it would be a No, though.  A bit tricky.

This is a difficult case to sort out. The idea of clearing registration roles versus ensuring one-person-one-vote is difficult. Previous arguments seem to have gone back and forth among the court. The wild card is Justice Gorsuch who seems to want to lecture the other scholars on the court. Let's see how conservative he really is (side note: I maintain that the term "conservative" has lost its meaning in the current climate of the court; partisanship in the court goes against the concept of judicial conservatism and translates into activism).
